comments.commentBody: AACNY, if the best argument you can make is that it's "a model that has worked thus far", consider that we fought a civil war to end another model that worked better "thus far" for its practitioners than for those whose labor made it possible.

Make no mistake: even if you don't work at Amazon, you work in an era in which these practices will become enshrined as a model of success. Unless and until some of the anger we see at a Bernie Sanders or a Donald Trump rally begins to find its target --the corporatists who value nothing --not human beings, communities, democracy, or the planet --more than profit. Bezos employs bright young people who want to feel like they are the elite. If they work hard, think what they' expect of the people below them on the food chain.

Now that America knows, will it care? We should demand an outside panel be hired to look into the culture at Amazon and publish the results before we buy another thing.

Yes, indeed. I would only add that, strangely enough, the picture we are getting of how Amazon operates is an eery echo of the capitalism Marx described. And yet we are always told that modern capitalism isn't like what Marx wrote about at all--it's vastly improved and more humanistic.

Amazon model does not strike me as workplace of the future. What it is is workplace with the generality of idea and plan set (by Bezos of course), then individuals are brought in with not purpose of maximizing their potential in any broad creative sense but rather to push them in a quite military sense--strain them for all they're worth...after all Amazon with its practice is very similar to the logistics, delivery aspect of a military campaign. This is why the drone idea of delivery for Amazon is so seductive--it overlaps with ideas for its use in the military although the military obviously has the drone in the public eye as a weapon.

This is not to say Amazon cannot be a model of work for the future--we can imagine the U.S. as a whole taking on a capitalistic/militaristic air beyond what we have today and the private sector controlled in a military sense (aided by surveillance technology, etc.) and people driven. The big problem though is still the need to create a work environment which maximizes creative power and that is quite dissimilar to the Bezos model. Creative power and long range view and development depends on humans quite autonomous in their decision when to rest and drive hard--in fact it depends on people who are quite intelligent about doctoring themselves in the widest sense of the word. Creative people learn methods of resting and driving their brains which are still novel compared to what occurs in the modern work environment.

I am in college and I rent or buy all my books on Amazon, even if they are more expensive. Why? Let me tell you.

Just this summer, I was two days late to return my Amazon rentals. I had to pay a $10 extension charge. I emailed Amazon, saying sorry, and that I was late because I was moving back home.

The same day, a gentleman from Amazon emailed me back, saying that it was ok; he had refunded my $10, and wished my luck for the fall semester! Which other company in the world would do that? Certainly not my local bookstore.

My dad is old-fashioned and never buys online--except from Amazon. He just trusts them. If something goes wrong--heck, if we do something wrong!--Amazon will apologize and pay us back. No other company like it. That's why it gets our business!

You can get the same social contract under communism, fascism, theocracies, military dictatorships, democracies... and I can assure you that there are many companies with this attitude toward work and their employees whose overlords have absolutely no chance of being considered libertarians, and would be outraged to get the label.

While people differ in their access to resources, at some point working in an environment under constant harsh competitive scrutiny tends to diminish the role of chance more than any other human social system.

Austrian economics, e.g. of von Mises or later, is a fantasyland.

von Mises interestingly was a product of the fascinating Austro-Hungarian empire that dissolved after WWI. His parents were Austrian Jews, a very interesting society itself at the time, but he was born in Lvov, an Austro-Hungarian outpost, which is now in far western Ukraine. When one reads his most famous work, Human Nature, the tone of the book is laughably self-assured about almost entirely false assertions. Fantasyland.

The Austrian School of Economics teaches that the inducement to invest derives its motivation from widening price margins, not unfounded optimism. However, in order for these price margins to dilate two things must happen: First, some consumption must be foregone so that a greater savings rate causes interest rates to fall and, second, consumer prices must be allowed to fall in consequence of that abstention. Only if both of these criteria are met, and they are met if the supply of money remains stable throughout, will the supply side become more capitalized and land and labour not now required to supply that amount of consumption set aside will be redeployed in early B2B where price margins are most favorable.

However, if a central bank guided by Keynes attempts to reflate consumer prices to gain a trade-off with re-employment of involuntary labour, the rational basis for the inducement to invest in early B2B is taken away. So yes, if you want the central bank to interfere in the price level, all is left is some irrational motivation you call the confidence fairy. but this is like shooting a runner in the foot and then claiming he has no motivation to win. Keynes's charge against Pigou and Say was composed from within the perspective of a loose fiat monetary system, not a sound monetary system where prices capture real diminishing marginal values.

Thank you for this touching piece of journalism. Despite all of the tragic stories like Paula Coopers--told and untold--our criminal justice system continually balks at the most effective and humane methods of reducing crime. We too often extol the deterrent qualities of the prison atmosphere, the isolation, the violence. Indeed, it is a hellish environment that would repulse anyone. But the very things that are heralded as disincentives to criminal behavior are those which also exacerbate the mental illnesses that lead one to behave criminally.
Sweeping reforms of this system are some of the steepest uphill battles because the ones we are fighting for are those who've hurt us in the past. For many, it is difficult to exercise compassion for a person they see as a monster, a threat--to someone like Bill Pelke, a perpetrator. But through the grace of his grandmother he was able to see that all of us have troubles, some more than others, and all of us need love and support; the most troubled among us deserve that help more than any.
Sadly, I think it will take a nation of Bill Pelkes to cause any substantive change. I hope that, with the help of people like you, who are the voice of the voiceless, we can someday reform the system in a way that digs to the roots of an individual's behavior to help them heal from the bottom up, and the inside out.

This woman did a terrible thing; she had a dreadful childhood, and her victim had a dreadful death.  Her abuser in childhood had no mercy on her, and she had none on the good elderly lady who died at her hands.   She ended in suicide and despair.  But in her life she also did some good, and tried to, obviously.  There are disabled people with helper animals she trained, and others no doubt, from the description we have of her later life.  No story is a simple story, in the end.  May God have mercy on her soul, as her victim would, I believe, be the first to say.  And may we find mercy in ourselves for each other, so that this world might be relieved of a little of its trouble because of us.
